data.title: Cinema Parrot Disco
data.meta_description: Posts about Tank Girl written by table9mutant
data.text:
Here are three quickies for three shitty movies. I wasted enough time watching them so I don‚Äôt want to spend much time writing about them. Here we go!

Tank Girl (1995)

Directed by Rachel Talalay

Based on Tank Girl comic by Alan Martin & Jamie Hewlett

Starring: Lori Petty, Ice-T, Naomi Watts, Malcolm McDowell, Iggy Pop, Scott Coffey, James Hong, Don Harvey, Jeff Kober, Reg E Cathey

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

Tank Girl is set in a drought-ravaged Australia, years after a catastrophic impact event. It follows the antihero Tank Girl (Petty) as she, Jet Girl (Watts), and genetically modified supersoldiers called the Rippers fight ‚ÄúWater & Power‚Äù, an oppressive corporation led by Kesslee (McDowell).

My Opinion:

I recently read a collection of early Tank Girl comics (which I reviewed yesterday HERE) so figured I better finally watch the movie adaptation afterwards despite it being pretty widely trashed. While reading Tank Girl, I kept thinking ‚Äúhow could this actually work as a movie?‚Äù. The answer, of course, is that this movie doesn‚Äôt work. What a mess‚Ä¶

I‚Äôll start with some positives: I didn‚Äôt mind Lori Petty as Tank Girl and thought she had the right look & attitude. I‚Äôll try to ignore the fact that she‚Äôs not at all Australian! I didn‚Äôt love her as Tank Girl (I‚Äôm sure someone else might have been better although I‚Äôm not sure who) but I didn‚Äôt hate her. She seemed to have fun with the role, anyway. Tank Girl is an awesome character and I think that does come through in the movie even though they don‚Äôt quite capture her spirit. And, um‚Ä¶ Another positive?? Let‚Äôs see‚Ä¶ The soundtrack is pretty good! Although I would‚Äôve liked much more punk plus they should‚Äôve tried to use bands mentioned in the comic (but a ‚Äúscore by Ennio Morricone‚Äù actually wouldn‚Äôt have worked even if the comic liked to credit him with its score). üòâ

In the comic, there wasn‚Äôt much of a storyline. Tank Girl was daft (and usually drunk) and the whole thing was crazy & all over the place. I liked that. I‚Äôve only read the earliest of the Tank Girl comics so don‚Äôt know how many I missed or if there‚Äôs actually a similar story to the one in the movie at some point but I didn‚Äôt think it worked. The story & the script sucked. Malcolm McDowell was a pretty crap villain and‚Ä¶ Naomi Watts was in this?! I didn‚Äôt know that beforehand ‚Äì she must be embarrassed now.

I wondered how they‚Äôd deal with Tank Girl‚Äôs boyfriend being a kangaroo and, although the movie doesn‚Äôt really manage to pull it off, I‚Äôm not sure how you ever could portray that in a film without it looking cheesy as hell. I like this bit of trivia at IMDB:

‚ÄúMGM insisted on cutting a scene of Tank Girl and her kangaroo boyfriend Booga reclining after sex, despite spending $5,000 on a prosthetic penis for Booga.‚Äù

I don‚Äôt know what else to say about this movie. It just didn‚Äôt work but, to be fair, I think it‚Äôs a very hard comic to adapt. I do wonder if it would work nowadays with the right director since comic book movies have gotten a lot better and ‚Äúdarker‚Äù. I‚Äôd like to see a violent, R-rated version. Like Dredd but with a sense of humor? I don‚Äôt know ‚Äì it still probably wouldn‚Äôt work but I did read that this movie was very heavily cut & that the director, Rachel Talalay, had no control over that so I suppose that didn‚Äôt help. I‚Äôm giving it a higher rating than I think it deserves because I really like the character of Tank Girl and, at the very least, I don‚Äôt think the movie tainted the character. But I‚Äôd like to see that fake kangaroo penis.

My Rating: 5/10

Class Of 1999 (1989)

Directed by Mark L Lester

Starring: Bradley Gregg, Traci Lind, Malcolm McDowell, Stacy Keach, Patrick Kilpatrick, Pam Grier, John P Ryan, Darren E Burrows, Joshua John Miller, Sean Sullivan

Plot Synopsis: (via IMDB)

Robot teachers have been secretly placed in the schools where the students have run riot. The teachers do a good job of controlling the unruly youngsters, until they go too far and some students get suspicious.

My Opinion:

On paper (or on a screen since that‚Äôs how we read everything now), this movie sounds awesome. To me, at least. The synopsis (killer robot teachers in a high school!), the cool poster & the fact that it‚Äôs from the 1980s had me all excited to watch this movie that I‚Äôd somehow never even heard of. Well, damn ‚Äì it‚Äôs not good. What a disappointment! I was hoping it would at least be a low budget sci-fi cult classic type of thing like Hardware or something (yes! I got yet another Hardware mention into a post!). I didn‚Äôt hate it but it‚Äôs not very good despite having so much potential to be something I‚Äôd like.

One thing I always love about watching movies from this time period is seeing familiar faces from my favorite era and Class Of 1999 has lots of these. Look ‚Äì a Tank Girl connection with Malcolm McDowell! He plays the school‚Äôs principal in this ‚Äì I think Hollywood had him on speed dial for these types of movies back then. The movie‚Äôs hero (Bradley Gregg ‚Äì a teenage delinquent who‚Äôs actually a ‚Äúgood guy‚Äù) is in two of my favorite movies: he‚Äôs Eyeball Chambers in Stand By Me and also the character whose death topped My Top Ten Nightmare On Elm Street Deaths in Dream Warriors!!!

The robot teachers are played by Patrick Kilpatrick, John P Ryan & Pam Grier (with dodgy-looking fake robot boobs). Stacy Keach is the main baddie in charge of the robots and for some reason seductively eats a banana? I immediately recognized Sean Sullivan as the drunk one who Garth doesn‚Äôt want spewing in the Mirth Mobile in Wayne‚Äôs World. Finally, Bradley Gregg‚Äôs sweet little delinquent brother is played by Joshua John Miller(!), who (whom?) I know very well from lots of 80‚Äôs movies & TV shows including my favorite episode of Highway To Heaven. Haha! Highway To Heaven!! I was such a nerd. I just looked him up & he co-wrote the screenplay for The Final Girls. What?! I should really try to watch that‚Ä¶

To be honest, I‚Äôm not sure what actually made this movie so bad. Yes, the acting is pretty rubbish and the special effects look dodgy and the script isn‚Äôt the greatest but I still can‚Äôt help but look at these images and the overall plot & cast and think that this is exactly my type of movie. I think it didn‚Äôt help that, when it started and we saw the exaggerated ‚Äúfuturistic 1999 punk kids‚Äù, it reminded me of the teenagers in Class Of Nuke ‚ÄòEm High. I‚Äôm pretty damn sure that no movie ever wants to make you immediately think of a Troma film.

Also, I watched this and the Bronies documentary very late one night as they were both about to disappear from Netflix. I kept falling asleep through both of them so I may have not fully given this movie a chance. Okay ‚Äì I think I‚Äôm now trying to talk myself into liking Class Of 1999 for some reason?? It‚Äôs an okay film but extremely dated and would only possibly be appreciated by someone my age who likes this sort of thing. I‚Äôm glad I watched it but I‚Äôm not too bothered that it has disappeared from Netflix. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôd have appreciated it more if I‚Äôd seen it when I was 15 or so. Has anyone seen the director‚Äôs previous film, Class Of 1984, which sounds like the exact same movie minus the robots? It has a higher IMDB rating. Hmm‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll watch that too if it shows up on Netflix!

My Rating: 5.5/10

Bronies: The Extremely Unexpected Adult Fans of My Little Pony (2012)

Directed by Laurent Malaquais

Produced by Anglie Brown, Morgan Peterson, Michael Brockhoff, Tara Strong, Lauren Faust & John de Lancie

Starring: A bunch of bronies!

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

Bronies: The Extremely Unexpected Adult Fans of My Little Pony (formerly titled BronyCon: The Documentary) is a 2012 documentary film centering on bronies, the adult fans of the 2010 animated television series, My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic.

My Opinion:

I said I didn‚Äôt want to waste much time talking about these movies but I did blather on a bit in my other two reviews. Well, this one will truly be short as there‚Äôs not much to say. I find the ‚ÄúBronies‚Äù thing sort of fascinating as I still don‚Äôt understand why a bunch of grown men have supposedly latched onto My Little Pony but this documentary doesn‚Äôt really explore the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù at all. It‚Äôs just not a very good or in-depth documentary and was quite boring considering its odd topic.

I actually don‚Äôt remember if the above guy was in the documentary but this is one of many photos that come up if you Google ‚ÄúBronies‚Äù (I don‚Äôt think the guys I used in the photo at the very top were in it). You‚Äôd think I‚Äôd remember if he was but I can barely remember a thing about this now. That‚Äôs the problem ‚Äì the documentary failed to make a bizarre topic at all interesting. I do, however, remember the below guy as I kept thinking he looked like Corey Feldman.

I‚Äôd say that you‚Äôd probably only want to watch this documentary if you‚Äôre a fan of My Little Pony. I actually found the bits with the voice actors (Tara Strong and, oh my god ‚Äì Q from Star Trek: The Next Generation, John de Lancie!) & the creator of the Friendship Is Magic series (Lauren Faust) more interesting than the interviews with the fans of the show.

Not surprisingly, one of the Bronies talked a little bit of the bullying he‚Äôd had to endure thanks to being a fan of the show (if I remember correctly, he had a gun pulled on him? God bless America!). That kind of thing always pisses me off because, although it may seem strange to a lot of us, these guys aren‚Äôt exactly hurting anyone by liking My Little Pony. I guess it was a little disappointing that the psychological aspect of what exactly it is about this show that has apparently drawn some grown men to it wasn‚Äôt explored but, hey, this was someone‚Äôs project and they did a decent enough job gathering together fans & those involved with the show. I‚Äôm sure it didn‚Äôt have a huge budget‚Ä¶ I‚Äôd be interested to know what My Little Pony fans thought of it but I must admit that I don‚Äôt personally know any adult fans (although I did love old school My Little Pony as a young girl!).

This is the one I had!!!

My Rating: 5/10

I figured I should end this post with something from the Tank Girl soundtrack, which had potential but could‚Äôve been much better overall. This is one of my two favorites from the soundtrack (I‚Äôll post the other for Music Video Friday this week): Richard Hell And The Voidoids ‚Äì Blank Generation:

Happy New Year, everyone! Wow ‚Äì I‚Äôve read a record 14 books in 2015! (That‚Äôs a lot for me. Hey, I‚Äôm a movie blogger ‚Äì not a book blogger). üôÇ

I‚Äôm really bad about getting around to doing book reviews so I‚Äôve only reviewed a few of these (I‚Äôve included links to the full reviews I have done). For the remainder, I figured I‚Äôd just do some very short mini-reviews right here right now. And, as my regulars know, my Top Ten lists rarely contain ten things so it seemed stupid to ignore four books when I‚Äôve only read 14.

So here are My Top Ten (14‚Ä¶) Books Read In 2015, counting down to my favorite:

14. The Gospel According To Drew Barrymore by Pippa Wright

I believe this is what they call ‚Äúchick lit‚Äù? Which isn‚Äôt very ‚Äúme‚Äù but my hubby picked this up for me based on the title since he knows I‚Äôm a fan of Drew Barrymore. I thought that was very sweet & thoughful of him! üôÇ Anyway, I really liked the concept. Through flashbacks, we watch the relationship develop between two (40ish?) best friends. They‚Äôre very different from one another but we see how they bonded over Drew Barrymore movies at various points in their lives (such as E.T. & Poison Ivy). Unfortunately, the book just isn‚Äôt very good. I didn‚Äôt like one of the women and the Drew Barrymore gimmick really did feel like nothing more than a gimmick ‚Äì the references to her felt awkward & forced. It was a good idea but without that gimmick, you‚Äôre left with two characters I really didn‚Äôt give a crap about. My Rating: 2/5

13. Florence & Giles by John Harding

I grabbed this from the library as I‚Äôd been wanting to read it for a while based on The Times quote on the front cover: ‚ÄúImagine The Turn Of The Screw reworked by Edgar Allan Poe‚Äù. It sounded like it would be all gothic & atmospheric but it was pretty disappointing. A young girl in the late 1800s must protect her younger brother from a sinister & otherworldly new governess after the mysterious death of the previous woman who cared for them. The girl (and narrator if I remember correctly??) isn‚Äôt allowed to read but teaches herself & reads loads of books in secret. It‚Äôs caused her to develop a strange sort of language of her own and having to read the book with all her odd words took some getting used to (and was slightly annoying). The girl also isn‚Äôt that easy to like and the book is extremely slow until finally picking up in the final half. It was a good story but not a very fun read. I actually think it could make for a great film if the right people were involved. My Rating: 2.5/5

12. The Shock Of The Fall by Nathan Filer

My favorite books to read are always horror, sci-fi or fantasy (which will be obvious when we get to the top of my list) but I do try to sometimes read bestsellers or ones that have awards slapped on their covers (like this one) which are probably bullshit half the time anyway. This is an example of a book that was pretty good and plenty of people probably liked it but, like the previous book, it just didn‚Äôt really work for me. Oh! I also judge books by their covers and this has a good one. And I was intrigued by the back cover (which I‚Äôve grabbed here from Goodreads): ‚ÄúI‚Äôll tell you what happened because it will be a good way to introduce my brother. His name‚Äôs Simon. I think you‚Äôre going to like him. I really do. But in a couple of pages he‚Äôll be dead. And he was never the same after that.‚Äù See? Sounds interesting. This is a book where you‚Äôll easily find out what it‚Äôs about if you read anything whatsoever about it but if you like knowing nothing other than what‚Äôs on the back cover, skip over this next part. SPOILER: This book is about mental illness (schizophrenia) and told from the viewpoint of the young adult (Matt) who is suffering from it. It‚Äôs a fairly unique book & I‚Äôd recommend it if it sounds to you like one you‚Äôd like. I have to say it‚Äôs actually a better book than my next two choices but, as always, I rank mainly by my level of enjoyment & I found myself not really wanting to pick this one up much so it took me quite a long time to finish. My Rating: 3/5

11. The Maze Runner by James Dashner

I admit to enjoying Young Adult books, especially as the current trend seems to be YA books that are dystopian and/or post-apocalyptic. I love dystopian and/or post-apocalyptic! I don‚Äôt normally do it this way around but I saw The Maze Runner movie first and I liked it so decided to read the books. Well, I‚Äôve read the first two so far and will continue in order to see how they end but I‚Äôve certainly read far better YA books. I also get the feeling that the story is going nowhere plus the author has a strange writing style that many people don‚Äôt seem to like. I‚Äôve reviewed this & The Scorch Trials in full if you want to click on the links. My Rating: 2.5/5

10. The Scorch Trials by James Dashner

This & The Maze Runner are pretty interchangeable but I suppose I‚Äôve put this higher as reading it was a bit more enjoyable since I didn‚Äôt see the movie first so didn‚Äôt know what would happen. Meh. Yeah. Again, not the greatest book‚Ä¶ I just like the overall concept, which is why I‚Äôm continuing with the series. My Rating: 2.5/5

9. The Unlikely Pilgrimage Of Harold Fry by Rachel Joyce

Not to be all snobby as I certainly don‚Äôt read many ‚Äúworthy‚Äù classics or anything but this looked like one of those supermarket books you see old ladies reading on the bus. Well, I suppose it kind of is but, screw it, I AM an old lady on a bus! The basic story is simple: Retired Harold Fry decides to make a pilgrimage by foot across most of England to visit an old work colleague & friend named Queenie, who has written him to say that she is dying. It was a slow read to start but I was fairly hooked as Harold got closer & closer to reaching his destination. As you may expect, Harold goes on a ‚Äújourney of self-discovery‚Äù during his long walk and this was the best thing about the book and was handled quite well. Something becomes obvious pretty early on but it made me want to keep reading to find out exactly what happened & how. My Rating: 3/5

8. The Book Thief by Markus Zusak

I‚Äôve just finished this book and I can see why some people have told me that they really loved it. I wanted to like it a little more than I did. I‚Äôll say that Zusak did a great job developing some rich characters that I very much cared about. Liesel, a young girl in WWII Germany, is the central character and I liked her strong will. Even better, though, were the characters Liesel loved most (her foster parents and best friend plus two other important characters I won‚Äôt mention to avoid any spoilers). Unfortunately, despite some great characters, I felt something that I can‚Äôt quite put my finger on was ‚Äúmissing‚Äù from this book. I think the problem was that it was narrated by Death (as in, The Grim Reaper). It‚Äôs a better ‚Äúgimmick‚Äù than the Drew Barrymore thing above and I didn‚Äôt mind it at first but, in the end, I think it actually got in the way of what was a good enough story without any gimmicks. Also, the ending felt rather abrupt & rushed after this long journey that we‚Äôve just gone on with all these characters (it‚Äôs a pretty thick book). It was a good book & I‚Äôm interested in seeing the movie now but I wish it was higher on this list. My Rating: 3.5/5

7. Tank Girl by Jamie Hewlett and Alan Martin

This is the second (of two!) graphic novels that I‚Äôve read (the other being Watchmen). Wait ‚Äì is this a graphic novel? It‚Äôs more of a collection of several comics‚Ä¶ I think?? Is there a difference? This sort of thing is something I have NO knowledge in but I have to say that I did enjoy Tank Girl. She‚Äôs a cool character and I really appreciated the (inappropriate) humor (it took me a while to read it all as I had to keep putting it away someplace where my young daughter wouldn‚Äôt grab it). I mean, Tank Girl has sex with a kangaroo. Whaaaat? It‚Äôs pretty damn bizarre but it‚Äôs fun and I was entertained. I suppose I should watch the horrible-looking movie that doesn‚Äôt appear to resemble the comic much now? Or‚Ä¶ Should I not?? My Rating: 3.5/5

6. NOS4A2 by Joe Hill

I read my first two Joe Hill books this year & I have to say that, so far, I may end up almost liking his work as much as his dad‚Äôs. This one seems to be a favorite but I enjoyed the other book more and found that I didn‚Äôt really care that much about the characters in this. But it‚Äôs a good & very original story. You can read my full review at the above link. My Rating: 4/5

5. Revival by Stephen King

Stephen King is and always will be my favorite author so I‚Äôm going to put a book of his fairly high on any list. I‚Äôve not yet reviewed this one but I will try to do a full review soon as it‚Äôs a King book so I‚Äôll keep this short. For now I‚Äôll say that this isn‚Äôt one of his best (it probably ranks somewhere in the lower middle for me if I were to do a list of all the King books I‚Äôve read). I find that I‚Äôm quite often a little disappointed with how King‚Äôs books end and this one has the same problem of starting out great but then kind of fizzling out at the end. I‚Äôll say that King once again draws a very detailed picture of small town American life which I can always relate to in his books and what makes me love his work so much. I was very much drawn into this small town where a young boy and tragic preacher reside. I just wish these two main characters had remained as interesting in the second half of the book as they grew older (the book spans many years). Well, I enjoyed it anyway ‚Äì read it if you love King. I enjoyed it more than his son‚Äôs NOS4A2 but will admit that Hill‚Äôs book was probably a little better than this one. My Rating: 3.5/5

4. Horns by Joe Hill

I suppose Joe Hill‚Äôs NOS4A2 is a slightly better book than Revival and also Horns but I read this one first & actually enjoyed it the most of this father/son trio that I read this year. It‚Äôs weird, especially as it gets to the end, and not everyone would like it but it was quite refreshing to read something so totally unique & unpredictable. You can read my full double review of this and NOS4A2 at the above link. My Rating: 4/5

3. Tuf Voyaging by George R.R. Martin

This is the first and only George R.R. Martin book I‚Äôve ever read and I loved it! I got the Game Of Thrones book last Christmas but haven‚Äôt yet had the energy to embark on that massive journey so when a woman I work with brought in a bunch of books that she was getting rid of, I was excited to see this standalone Martin book so I could see what his work was like. I can only compare this to the Game Of Thrones TV show but I‚Äôd have to say it‚Äôs quite different from that. This is sci-fi comedy! I‚Äôve read very few books in this genre but one happens to be my all-time favorite book (The Hitchhiker‚Äôs Guide To The Galaxy) so this one was perfect for me and I enjoyed it immensely. I suppose I also owe this one a full-length review at some point‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll just say that, although Martin‚Äôs books are clearly popular, I had no idea of what a great writer this guy really is and it has me definitely wanting to read more of his stuff. I‚Äôll also admit this: I‚Äôm a casual reader & clearly like light & easy entertainment. My vocabulary is limited (as evidenced by my so-called ‚Äúreviews‚Äù üòâ ) and I‚Äôve never had to look up so many words for their definitions while reading a book as I did while reading this. (Not tons, maybe six or seven words). But that‚Äôs awesome ‚Äì I don‚Äôt have to do that with my YA books! This guy truly has a great way with words and his characters (especially Tuf) felt so alive. And it was actually funny! After watching Game Of Thrones, full of so much tragic death, I wasn‚Äôt sure what to expect of a sci-fi comedy from the same author. Plus the story itself had me hooked. Loved it. Can anyone recommend any of his other work? My Rating: 4.5/5

2. The Martian by Andy Weir

I can‚Äôt believe I never had a chance to watch this film considering how much I loved the book! Oh well ‚Äì I‚Äôll catch it at some point. I did at least review this book in full so I can keep this short. I guess I really do love my sci-fi comedies (although this is more sci-fi than comedy but I loved the central character‚Äôs amazing sense of humor). I find very few books to be perfect (I‚Äôm almost always disappointed with the endings) but I really can‚Äôt fault this one in any way other than it ending too abruptly. But I suppose that‚Äôs because I was enjoying it so much. The Martian is easily now an all-time favorite of mine and I highly recommend it. My Rating: 5/5

1. Ready Player One by Ernest Cline

I‚Äôm so disappointed in myself for not getting around to reviewing this yet even though it‚Äôs the very first book I read after receiving it for Christmas last year. Thanks to anyone who has actually read this (really long & rambling) post! I‚Äôm sorry to do this to you now at my number one but I‚Äôm not going to say much about this one. Yet. It deserves a full-length review from me as it‚Äôs my favorite book in a very long time & nothing could be more ‚ÄúME‚Äú! This was written for Eighties-loving geeks like me by an Eighties-loving geek and I absolutely adored it. I had so much fun reading this one. I hope the movie does it justice! My Rating: 5/5
